fever.description: Fever is a temporary rise in body temperature, often due to an underlying illness or infection. It is a natural defense mechanism that helps the body fight off pathogens. Normal body temperature is about 98.6°F (37°C); fever is generally considered to be 100.4°F (38°C) or higher.
causes: Viral or bacterial infections (e.g., flu, pneumonia, COVID-19)
symptoms: Elevated body temperature (measured with a thermometer)
stages: Onset: Feeling cold, shivering, rising temperature
Plateau: Temperature stabilizes, feeling hot, sweating
Defervescence: Temperature returns to normal, sweating may increase
prevention: Practice good hand hygiene (wash hands regularly)
Avoid close contact with sick individuals
Stay up to date with vaccinations
Maintain a healthy lifestyle to support immune function
lifestyle_tips: Rest as much as possible to help your body recover
Drink plenty of fluids (water, clear broths, electrolyte drinks)
Eat light, nutritious foods if you feel hungry
Wear lightweight, breathable clothing
Keep your room well-ventilated and at a comfortable temperature
treatment_options: Hydration: drink water, oral rehydration solutions if needed
Seek medical advice if unsure about the cause
risk_factors: Weakened immune system (elderly, infants, chronic illness)
Recent travel to areas with infectious diseases
complications: Organ damage (rare, in prolonged high fever)
when_to_seek_help: Rash that doesn't fade when pressed
Fever in infants under 3 months old

faqs.q: Is fever always a sign of infection?
faqs.a: No, fever can also be caused by heat exhaustion, autoimmune diseases, or as a side effect of medication or vaccination.

faqs.q: Should I always treat a fever?
faqs.a: Mild fevers do not always require treatment unless they cause discomfort. Focus on rest and hydration. Treat high or persistent fevers, or if you have risk factors.

faqs.q: Can I go to work or school with a fever?
faqs.a: No. Stay home to rest and avoid spreading illness to others.

pneumonia.description: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus. It can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
stages: Mild: Symptoms similar to a bad cold
Moderate: More severe symptoms, may need medical care
Severe: Hospitalization may be required
lifestyle_tips: Rest and stay hydrated
Follow your doctor’s treatment plan
Avoid contact with sick people
Use a humidifier to ease breathing
when_to_seek_help: High fever that does not improve

faqs.a: Some types are, especially viral and bacterial pneumonia. Practice good hygiene to reduce risk.
Mild cases recover in 1-2 weeks, severe cases may take longer.

dengue.description: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection causing high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding.
causes: Dengue virus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes (A. aegypti, A. albopictus)
stages: Febrile phase: High fever, headache, pain
Critical phase: Risk of shock, bleeding (usually after fever subsides)
Recovery phase: Gradual improvement
prevention: Use bed nets and window screens
lifestyle_tips: Rest and drink plenty of fluids
Monitor for warning signs (bleeding, severe pain, persistent vomiting)
Seek medical care if symptoms worsen
treatment_options: Avoid NSAIDs (ibuprofen, aspirin) due to bleeding risk
risk_factors: Living or traveling in tropical/subtropical areas
Previous dengue infection (risk of severe dengue)
complications: Severe dengue (dengue hemorrhagic fever, dengue shock syndrome)

faqs.a: Yes, by avoiding mosquito bites and eliminating breeding sites.
A vaccine exists but is not widely available in all countries.

tuberculosis.description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs but can affect other organs. It is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
causes: Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria, spread through airborne droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
stages: Latent TB: Infected but no symptoms, not contagious
Active TB: Symptoms present, contagious
prevention: Early detection and treatment of active cases
lifestyle_tips: Take all medications as prescribed
Eat a nutritious diet
Avoid close contact with others until cleared by doctor
when_to_seek_help: Severe chest pain or difficulty breathing

faqs.a: Yes, with proper antibiotics taken for the full course.

faqs.q: Can I catch TB from sharing food?
faqs.a: No, TB is spread through the air, not by sharing food or drinks.

hepatitis_b.description: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease. It is spread through contact with blood or other body fluids.
causes: Hepatitis B virus (HBV), spread by blood, sexual contact, or from mother to child at birth.
stages: Acute: Short-term illness, may resolve on its own
Chronic: Long-term infection, risk of liver damage
prevention: Avoid sharing needles or personal items
lifestyle_tips: Avoid alcohol to protect your liver
Eat a healthy, balanced diet
Get regular medical checkups
when_to_seek_help: Vomiting blood or passing black stools

faqs.a: Acute hepatitis B can resolve on its own. Chronic hepatitis B can be managed but not always cured.

faqs.q: Can I get hepatitis B from casual contact?
faqs.a: No, it is not spread by hugging, sharing food, or casual contact.

migraine.description: Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by intense, throbbing headaches, often on one side of the head, sometimes accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.
causes: Certain foods and drinks (cheese, chocolate, alcohol)
stages: Prodrome: Subtle changes hours or days before
Aura: Visual or sensory disturbances (not in all cases)
Attack: Severe headache phase
Postdrome: Fatigue, confusion after headache
prevention: Maintain regular sleep and meal schedule
lifestyle_tips: Keep a headache diary to track triggers
Practice relaxation techniques
Exercise regularly
when_to_seek_help: Headache with fever, stiff neck, confusion

faqs.a: There is no cure, but symptoms can be managed with medication and lifestyle changes.
Most are not, but seek help for sudden, severe, or new types of headache.

anemia.description: Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body’s tissues. It can make you feel tired and weak.
stages: Mild: Few or no symptoms
Moderate: Noticeable fatigue, weakness
Severe: Shortness of breath, chest pain, fainting
prevention: Eat iron-rich foods (red meat, beans, spinach)
Treat underlying causes of blood loss
lifestyle_tips: Eat a balanced diet with iron, B12, and folate
Avoid tea/coffee with meals (can reduce iron absorption)
Get regular blood tests if at risk

faqs.a: Yes, with a healthy diet and treating underlying causes.
Mild anemia is common and treatable, but severe anemia can be dangerous if untreated.

chickenpox.description: Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy, blister-like rash. It is most common in children but can affect adults.
causes: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), spread by respiratory droplets or direct contact with rash.
symptoms: Itchy, blister-like rash (starts on face/trunk, spreads)
stages: Incubation: 10-21 days after exposure
Prodrome: Mild fever, malaise
Rash: Red spots, then blisters, then scabs
lifestyle_tips: Keep fingernails trimmed to prevent scratching
Wear loose, comfortable clothing
Use calamine lotion or oatmeal baths for itching

faqs.a: It is rare, but possible. Most people have lifelong immunity after infection or vaccination.
Yes, adults are at higher risk for severe complications.

covid_19.description: COVID-19 is a respiratory illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. It ranges from mild cold-like symptoms to severe pneumonia and can be fatal, especially in high-risk groups.
causes: SARS-CoV-2 virus, spread by respiratory droplets, aerosols, and contact with contaminated surfaces.
stages: Incubation: 2-14 days after exposure
Mild: Cold-like symptoms
Moderate: Pneumonia, persistent fever
Severe: Respiratory distress, hospitalization
prevention: Wear masks in crowded or indoor settings
lifestyle_tips: Monitor symptoms and oxygen levels
Isolate if sick or exposed
Stay hydrated and rest
Follow public health guidelines
treatment_options: Oxygen therapy or hospitalization if needed
when_to_seek_help: New confusion or inability to wake

faqs.q: Can I get COVID-19 more than once?
faqs.a: Yes, reinfection is possible, but vaccination reduces risk of severe illness.
Follow local health guidelines, usually at least 5-10 days from symptom onset or positive test.

diseases.description: The common cold and influenza (flu) are contagious viral infections affecting the respiratory tract. While both share similar symptoms, flu is usually more severe and can lead to complications, especially in vulnerable groups.
causes: Flu: Influenza A and B viruses
Spread by droplets from coughs, sneezes, or touching contaminated surfaces
symptoms: Mild to high fever (more common in flu)
stages: Incubation: 1-3 days after exposure
Onset: Sudden for flu, gradual for cold
Peak: Symptoms most severe (2-4 days)
Recovery: Symptoms gradually improve
prevention: Wash hands frequently with soap and water
Avoid touching face with unwashed hands
Wear a mask in crowded places during flu season
Maintain good ventilation in indoor spaces
Eat a balanced diet rich in vitamins C and D
lifestyle_tips: Stay home when sick to avoid spreading illness
Use tissues or elbow to cover coughs and sneezes
Disinfect commonly touched surfaces
Drink warm fluids (herbal teas, broths)
Use a humidifier to ease congestion
risk_factors: Chronic health conditions (asthma, diabetes, heart disease)
Lack of sleep or high stress

duration.flu: 5-7 days, with lingering fatigue up to 2 weeks

when_to_seek_help: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Fever or cough that improves but then returns or worsens

faqs.q: How can I tell the difference between a cold and the flu?
faqs.a: Flu symptoms are usually more sudden and severe, with higher fever and body aches. Colds are milder and develop gradually.

faqs.q: Can antibiotics treat a cold or flu?
faqs.a: No. Both are caused by viruses, so antibiotics are not effective.

faqs.q: When can I return to work or school?
faqs.a: Wait until you are fever-free for at least 24 hours without medication and symptoms are improving.

diarrhea.description: Diarrhea is the passage of loose, watery stools more than three times a day. It can be acute (short-term) or chronic (lasting more than 2 weeks). Most cases are mild and resolve on their own, but severe or persistent diarrhea can be dangerous, especially in children and the elderly.
causes: Bacterial infections (E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter)
symptoms: Dehydration (dry mouth, sunken eyes, little urination)
stages: Acute: Sudden onset, usually resolves in a few days
Persistent: Lasts 2-4 weeks
Chronic: Lasts more than 4 weeks, may indicate underlying condition
prevention: Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water
Eat properly cooked and fresh foods
Use separate cutting boards for raw meat and vegetables
lifestyle_tips: Drink oral rehydration solutions (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes
Eat small, frequent meals (BRAT diet: Bananas, Rice, Applesauce, Toast)
Avoid dairy, fatty, or spicy foods during acute episodes
Rest and avoid strenuous activity
Monitor for signs of dehydration
treatment_options: Clear fluids intake (water, broths, electrolyte drinks)
risk_factors: Travel to areas with poor sanitation
when_to_seek_help: Severe dehydration signs (dizziness, dry mouth, little urination)
Symptoms of severe dehydration (excessive thirst, dry mouth, little or no urination, severe weakness)
Signs of infection (high fever, confusion, rapid heartbeat)

faqs.q: Should I stop eating if I have diarrhea?
faqs.a: No. Eat small, bland meals as tolerated. Avoid dairy, fatty, or spicy foods until symptoms improve.

faqs.q: When should I see a doctor?
faqs.a: If you have blood in your stool, high fever, severe pain, or signs of dehydration, seek medical attention immediately.
Over-the-counter medicines can help, but avoid them if you have bloody diarrhea or high fever unless advised by a doctor.

lifestyle_changes: exercise at least 150 minutes per week
limit processed foods and sugary drinks
dietary_recommendations: choose whole grains over refined grains

when_to_seek_help: blood sugar readings consistently above target range
frequent unexplained high or low blood sugar
diabetes.description: Diabetes is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels. It occurs either when the pancreas doesn't produce enough insulin (Type 1) or when the body becomes resistant to insulin (Type 2).

type1.description: An autoimmune condition where the body attacks insulin-producing cells

type2.description: A condition where the body becomes resistant to insulin

when_to_seek_help: blood pressure readings consistently above 130/80 mmHg
hypertension.description: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common condition where the long-term force of blood against artery walls is high enough to potentially cause health problems. It often develops over many years and can damage blood vessels and organs, particularly the heart, brain, kidneys, and eyes.

common_patterns.timing: Symptoms typically appear 10-15 days after infection
common_patterns.cycles: Fever cycles every 24-48 hours depending on species

personal_protection: stay in screened or air-conditioned rooms
environmental_control: maintain screens on windows and doors
medication: complete full course of preventive medication
start medication before entering malaria-risk areas

when_to_seek_help: fever with chills in malaria-prone areas
symptoms within 1 year of travel to endemic area
severe weakness or inability to sit/stand
malaria.description: Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites transmitted through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. The severity of malaria varies based on the species of plasmodium causing the infection.

risk_factors: living in or visiting endemic areas

Brush teeth twice daily and floss once daily
Keep nails clean and properly trimmed
Wear clean clothes and change them daily
Use tissue or elbow when coughing or sneezing
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces
personal_care: Use mild soap and clean towels
home_hygiene: Regular cleaning and disinfection of bathroom and kitchen
Regular washing of bedding and towels

dietary_guidelines: Eat at least 5 servings of various fruits and vegetables daily
Choose whole grains over refined grains
Limit processed foods and added sugars
Reduce sodium intake to less than 2300mg daily
Include healthy fats from nuts, seeds, and olive oil
meal_planning: Plan balanced meals with all food groups
Eat regular meals at consistent times

Exercise regularly but not too close to bedtime
